title: Araucaria cunninghamii
text:
Araucaria cunninghamii is a species of "<a href="Araucaria">Araucaria</a>" known as hoop pine. Other less commonly used names include colonial pine, Queensland pine, Dorrigo pine, Moreton Bay pine and Richmond River pine. The scientific name honours the <a href="botanist">botanist</a> and <a href="explorer">explorer</a> <a href="Allan%20Cunningham%20%28botanist%29">Allan Cunningham</a>, who collected the first specimens in the 1820s.
Habitat.
The species is found in the dry <a href="rainforest">rainforest</a>s of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> and <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a> and in <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>. The trees can live up to 450 years and grow to a height of 60 metres. The bark is rough, splits naturally, and peels easily.
Description.
The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> on young trees are awl-shaped, 1–2 cm long, about 2 mm thick at the base, and scale-like, incurved, 1–2 cm long and 4 mm broad on mature trees. The <a href="conifer%20cone">cones</a> are ovoid, 8–10 cm long and 6–8 cm diameter, and take about 18 months to mature. They disintegrate at maturity to release the nut-like edible <a href="seed">seed</a>s.
Subspecies.
There are two varieties:
Cultivation and other uses.
The <a href="wood">wood</a> is a high-quality timber that is particularly important to the plywood industry and also used for <a href="furniture">furniture</a>, <a href="Wood%20veneer">veneer</a>, <a href="joiner">joiner</a>y, <a href="panelling">panelling</a>, <a href="particle%20board">particle board</a>, <a href="flooring">flooring</a> and <a href="boat">boat</a>s. Most natural stands in Australia and Papua New Guinea have been depleted by logging. It is now mainly found on timber <a href="plantation">plantation</a>s; however, the species continues to thrive in protected areas, including <a href="Lamington%20National%20Park">Lamington National Park</a> where at least one walking track is named after it.
<a href="Indigenous%20Australians">Aboriginal Australians</a> used the <a href="resin">resin</a> as cement.
Pests.
The plantations in Queensland have been subject to damage by a native rat species, "<a href="Rattus%20tunneyi">Rattus tunneyi</a>", which digs to the roots of a semi-mature tree and kills it, the animal was declared a pest for this reason. The vulnerability of "A. cunninghamii" plantations to pest losses has caused some of them to be replaced by "<a href="Araucaria%20hunsteinii">A. hunsteinii</a>" which suffers less in plantation. Unspecified <a href="Microlepidoptera">Microlepidoptera</a> are significant pests of the <a href="conifer%20cone">pine cone</a>s of both.
Biological control.
"<a href="Cryptolaemus%20montrouzieri">Cryptolaemus montrouzieri</a>" is a <a href="coccinellidae">coccinellid</a> predator of <a href="mealybug">mealybug</a> and soft <a href="scale%20insect">scale insect</a> parasites of "A. cunninghamii", and has several characteristics that make it a good <a href="biological%20control">biocontrol</a> for use in plantations. Although they are less interested in other trees - by many multiples - "C. montrouzieri" does hunt the same pests in <a href="custard%20apple">custard apple</a> and <a href="citrus">citrus</a> plantations.
